awd_titl_txt: Learning Analytics in STEM Education Research Institute
awd_abstract_narration:
North Carolina State University (NCSU) will establish the Learning Analytics in STEM Education Research (LASER) Institute to build learning analytics capacity in STEM education research. The institute will provide professional development for early and mid-career STEM education researchers in learning analytics, a computational research methodology. The goal of the institute is to increase the capacity of researchers to understand and improve STEM learning and learning environments through the use of new sources of data and analytical approaches. The institute will be anchored by a week-long intensive training program consisting of hands-on learning labs, presentations from experts in the field, support for research planning and data analyses, and opportunities for networking and collaboration. In addition, follow up support will occur throughout the year.

The institute will prepare STEM education research scholars to: 1) understand the methodologies, applications, and ethical issues of learning analytics as these relate to understanding and improving STEM education, 2) gain proficiency in R, a free software environment applied to computational analysis techniques (e.g., network analysis, text mining, machine learning, and data dashboards) using real-world STEM education data, and 3) expand professional networks in support of STEM education research efforts. 

This research institute is funded by ECR (the core research program of the Education and Human Resources directorate) and attends specifically to critical aspects in research capacity building.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
Program Overview

The Learning Analytics in STEM Education Research (LASER) Institute addressed the growing demand for advanced research methodologies in STEM education. By equipping early and mid-career scholars with the tools and knowledge to leverage learning analytics (LA), the LASER Institute empowered researchers to examine and improve STEM learning environments. Spanning three cohorts from 2020 to 2023, this initiative directly impacted 142 researchers from institutions across 30 states and 7 countries, while prioritizing scholars from underrepresented groups and minority-serving institutions to broaden participation in STEM education research.

The LASER Institute was a year-long professional development program, featuring an intensive summer workshop and a sustained online community of practice. During the five-day summer workshops, scholars engaged in foundational and advanced learning labs covering topics such as machine learning, text mining, social network analysis, and data visualization using R. These workshops were complemented by webinars, office hours, and collaborative activities during the academic year, fostering an inclusive and supportive network of scholars. The program’s adaptability over its three-year duration ensured that scholars with diverse technical backgrounds could fully engage with the curriculum.

Intellectual Merit

The LASER Institute made significant contributions to the intellectual advancement of STEM education research. Scholars reported marked improvements in their ability to apply computational techniques to complex educational challenges. Participants developed research projects that utilized text mining to analyze qualitative data from educational institutions, employed machine learning to predict student retention, and applied social network analysis to explore collaboration patterns in online learning environments.

Scholars produced a comprehensive range of academic outputs that they attributed to their participation in LASER. Collectively, scholars reported over 80 academic products including, but are not limited to: 30 conference presentations and proceedings; 21 published journal articles, book chapters or books; 13 workshops, symposia, or service activities; 11 manuscripts in progress; 9 funded grants awarded and 6 submitted. This productivity underscored the program’s success in equipping participants with the technical and conceptual tools necessary to conduct impactful research and address pressing educational challenges.

Broader Impacts

The LASER Institute’s societal impacts are evident in its commitment to broadening participation in STEM education research. Across all three cohorts, the program recruited 142 scholars from a pool of 731 applicants, achieving a scholar demographic profile that reflects a strong commitment to diversity. Among scholars, approximately 72% were women and 57% came from minority racial and ethnic groups. Additionally, 21% of scholars were affiliated with minority-serving institutions. These efforts significantly exceeded national benchmarks for diversity in STEM fields and directly supported NSF’s goal of broadening participation among underrepresented groups.

Participants also applied their training to improve learning environments for diverse populations. LASER alumni developed tools to analyze equity gaps in STEM education, informed institutional decision-making through data analytics, and applied their skills to mentoring students and designing inclusive curricula. The Institute’s emphasis on actionable research, as well as an innovative grant program implemented in the final year, helped ensure that scholars not only advanced their careers but also contributed to systemic improvements in STEM education.

The program’s legacy extends beyond individual participants through the creation of a sustainable research infrastructure. LASER’s open-access curriculum, hosted on GitHub, includes comprehensive instructional modules made up of conceptual overviews, code-alongs, interactive case studies, essential readings, and assessment activities. These repositories provide an enduring resource for researchers worldwide. Additionally, the adoption of LASER’s methodologies and resources within participating universities and institutions ensures the program’s impact will continue for years to come.

Commitment to Excellence

LASER’s success was driven by a commitment to continuous improvement. Each year, the program refined its selection criteria, workshop structure, and curriculum based on participant feedback and evaluation. Recognizing the diversity in participants’ technical skills, LASER provided differentiated learning paths and enhanced scaffolding to support both novice and advanced users. These adaptations ensured scholars from varied backgrounds could succeed and benefit from the program. The Institute also reduced technical barriers by improving documentation, integrating cutting-edge tools like large language models, and offering extensive individual support.

The program’s emphasis on community-building further strengthened its outcomes. Scholars reported high levels of satisfaction with the Institute’s supportive and collaborative environment. Networking activities and research goal-setting sessions enabled participants to form meaningful professional connections and establish long-term research partnerships. These efforts created a vibrant scholarly community that continues to drive innovation and collaboration in STEM education research.

Conclusion

The LASER Institute represents a transformative model for capacity-building in STEM education research. By advancing scholars’ technical expertise, fostering diversity, and promoting actionable research, the program has made lasting contributions to both the intellectual and societal dimensions of STEM education. Its legacy is evident in the productive research careers of its participants, the enduring resources it has created, and the systemic improvements it has inspired. LASER’s achievements underscore the critical role of targeted professional development in shaping the future of STEM education and research.
